metadata.title: This is how you put the data in Data Science! | by Cassie Kozyrkov | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: This is how you put the data in Data Science!
metadata.description: One of my favorite recent additions to the Google Search family is Dataset Search. Yes, you heard that right. You can search for datasets just like you can search for images! Google’s vertical search…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: highest virtue in analytics is speed

all_paragraphs: One of my favorite recent additions to the Google Search family is Dataset Search. Yes, you heard that right. You can search for datasets just like you can search for images!
You can now search for datasets just like you search for images!

Google’s vertical search engines like Google Images or Google Scholar wouldn’t last long if no one used them, so their varieties tell you a little something about what people tend to look for on the internet. Images, videos, and news are hardly surprising. But datasets? There’s your hint that working with datasets isn’t just for three isolated professors in a faraway igloo. It’s big. …and it’s getting bigger.

What’s the catch? There isn’t one. This really is the same thing as searching with Google Images or Google Scholar, but for datasets. Over 20 million (!) datasets are currently indexed and available… and that index is growing quickly.
Today it puts 20 million datasets at your fingertips… and there will be more tomorrow.

Now that you know it exists, you can go play with it here or you can stick around for a discussion of how Dataset Search works and what it means for the data science profession and humanity in general.

Analytics is that part of data science that’s all about getting inspired quickly. Unlike statistics or machine learning, the highest virtue in analytics is speed. (To stay safe, good analysts form an immunity to jumping to conclusions before they’ve followed up in new data.)
Faster access to data gives you stronger analytics capabilities.

You know what you get when datasets are easy to find? Faster analytics! Dataset Search represents an incredible speed boost for all you professional analysts and data scientists out there. (But do remember to follow up more carefully with a statistical approach if you’re in danger of taking your inspiration seriously.)

If you grew up in a world where datasets were rare, precious, and often curated by professors or by data providers — as most of us did! — you might have a touch of unconscious bias: you assume that whoever is giving you the data takes responsibility for its quality (and probably has a PhD or two tucked away somewhere). If you mostly worked with datasets in a learning or scientific context, you might have formed the impression that datasets are lovingly massaged before they get to you.
Real life data science is a jungle, not a sacred space curated by your professors.

Set that bias aside for a moment and consider a different one: the toxic effect of data worship among laypeople. Anyone who has the tendency to pronounce data with a capital “D” might assume that all information packaged in structured form is useful and true. Hey, it’s not magic. Don’t believe everything you read and don’t believe every dataset either. Learn more about the nature of data and data worship here.

If you lived a life where most people giving you data were reputable and/or you were taught to worship data and science, you’re in for a nasty shock. Guess what! A dataset could be a bunch of structured rubbish. It could be broken. It could be made up. It could be six billion zeros. It could be anything at all. Just like the written word!
“If it’s written in a book, it must be true…”

Speaking of the written word: “If it’s written in a book, it must be true…” Right? Wrong! Even worse: “If it’s written online, it must be true…” I see the face you just pulled and I love it. Good. You’re skeptical. You should be. Now how about “If it’s written in a dataset, it must be true…”

There’s lots of junk out there since anyone can write whatever they want. You know better than to trust it. Instead, you take a moment to think about the source. Excellent, since that habit is going to keep you safe in the realm of data too.
If you’re in the habit of trusting data more than the written word, watch yourself.

If you’re in the habit of trusting data more than the written word, watch yourself. You might have that habit without realizing it. Don’t treat data as something capital-D sacred. Reorient toward your streetwise web habits, the ones you always use while searching Google Images or the web at large. You know Google doesn’t own or edit those cat pics or the invisibility potion recipe it serves up when you ask nicely. (You know those invisibility potions don’t work, right?) You know that quality varies and it’s up to you to think critically about the source before you believe everything you read. You know there’s all kinds of stuff out there on the interwebs and you’re long past gullibility. Well, mostly. Even the best of us occasionally click on those “One Weird Trick” links or outlandish news stories.
If you apply your usual streetwise internet search skepticism to Dataset Search, there’s no catch.
Treat Dataset Search results like any other internet search results. The tool will help you sift the haystack, but it’s up to you to double-check the quality of what the cat drags in.

But hey, if given the choice between a vast searchable cornucopia of cat images of varying quality and a small album of 3 beautifully curated cat images, I’d pick the former any day. (Well, I’d actually pick both because I’m greedy… and you can too. There’s nothing about these search tools that demands your monogamy.)

Not everything out there is good for you. That said, Google does try its best to fight spam and prioritize legitimate results. Yes, people will put spammy datasets out there to steal your attention and yes, we rank it to try to serve you the good stuff instead. Just like regular search. But you shouldn’t expect these things to be perfect.
All it takes to make your dataset searchable is adding metadata in schema.org to each web page that describes a dataset.

All it takes to make your dataset searchable is adding metadata in schema.org to each web page that describes a dataset. Anyone can do it, just like anyone can write a blog post. It could be rubbish (maybe this blog post is… uh-oh) so think critically about the source.
If you’re about to consume free range data, you need to keep your wits about you. Don’t believe everything you read.

The idea for schema.org was birthed in 2011 by a consortium drawn from the usual suspects: Google, Bing, Yandex, Microsoft, and Yahoo. They were tired of guessing the contents of scraped web pages, so they decided to create a common vocabulary that providers could use to tell them what was what. This vocabulary gets embedded in HTML to indicate which bits describe an event, an address, a recipe, and so forth. It’s a little schema (hence the name!) that describes different types of information. When you choose to add schema.org to your page and tell it the page has a dataset, that dataset becomes eligible to show up in the Dataset Search results.
Data providers use schema.org to tell us there’s a dataset on their page and describe some metadata about it.

This isn’t some Google-specific magic; it’s an open community standard that anyone can contribute to. Many companies have been using it behind the scenes for years. The Google-specific bit is your new ability to search those datasets with Dataset Search. We let data providers use schema.org to tell us there’s a dataset on their page and describe some metadata about it. Dataset Search is a lot like regular search, but the results are limited to pages that claim to have a dataset on them. Simple and useful.
When data came exclusively from a few large providers who took responsibility for curating each one carefully (such as governments and universities), smaller players lacked an avenue to share theirs.

Imagine this scenario: A group of high school girls is working on an extracurricular robotics project. They’re collecting plenty of data that might be handy for people with similar hobbies. They’re even willing to share it (how nice of them). They’ve put a link to it on their high school’s website. Their data just so happen to be exactly what you need to help your prototyping along. What now?

If their dataset isn’t searchable, you’ll never find it. If their data must be hosted by a curator (like a government) to be accessible, they’ll be told to get in line… and they’ll probably never get to the front. Providers who spend scarce resources on heavy curation only have time and attention a limited set of priority sources. The upshot? You’ll never know what you missed out on.

That’s why I find this whole dataset search paradigm so pretty. Sharing data (without an intermediary telling you to get lost) means that people can find and provide great resources even if they’ve got niche tastes… or obscure high school websites.
To participate in sharing searchable data:

I hope it doesn’t surprise you that the propensity to meet both of these conditions varies from field to field. Governments were among the first to index their datasets, so the kind of datasets they tend to collect (weather data, anyone?) are great candidates for your feeding frenzy, while proprietary data that’s expensive to collect will be sparsely available. That said, more data is being added every day and the search serves up doors to free and paid data alike. (A bit like those watermarked proprietary images in Google Images.) It’s up to you to pick which doors you’d like to go through and whether the toll is worth it.

A large user base for something like Dataset Search is a symbol of humanity’s evolution with respect to data science and data literacy. We are growing up as a species and extending the way that we can deploy our senses and the way that we communicate with information.
Data analytics is becoming everyone’s game.

We used to be impressed by the ability to open a single page on the internet, then by the ability to open 50 tabs in our browsers — one per datapoint — to eyeball that mess for patterns. Now we’re hungry for more. We want datasets we can shape and summarize quickly with code tools (like Python and R) built for the job. The data-fluent community has critical mass now; enough of us have skills to understand data and we’re no longer content with picture-covered written pages. (Of the kind you’re staring at right now. Hah.)

To consume information from sources like the one you’re reading right at this veeery moment, you need a particular kind of literacy. Your mind needs to be able to wrap itself around the written word. That’s a skill you take for granted. If very few people had the skill, this blog post wouldn’t exist. Google probably wouldn’t exist either.
Dataset Search represents a rising tide in the democratization of data literacy.

In the same way, Dataset Search represents a rising tide in the democratization of data literacy. This whole development is a way of clambering to the top of the mountain and yodeling, “Working with data isn’t a completely niche skill anymore!” It’s no longer limited to a few scribes chiseling hieroglyphics into clay tablets. (Oh, wait, that’s writing. Same idea though.)
Online datasets provide a new vehicle for self-expression that follows the same rules as the rest of the internet.
Dataset Search helps you find the gems among the chatter.

Datasets are becoming a widespread form of communication — a beautiful new language that many of us speak fluently and many more are studying every day. For those of us who’ve been speaking data since childhood, it’s a great relief to be able to get search results in our language.
Which is why my feelings about Dataset Search are straightforward: “Fiiiinally!”
If you had fun here and you’re looking for an applied AI course designed to be fun for beginners and experts alike, here’s one I made for your amusement:
Let’s be friends! You can find me on Twitter, YouTube, Substack, and LinkedIn. Interested in having me speak at your event? Use this form to get in touch.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Chief Decision Scientist, Google. ❤️ Stats, ML/AI, data, puns, art, theatre, decision science. All views are my own. twitter.com/quaesita
